content:
This is a sandbox-style game running a simple 2D physics engine. The player can generate balls of varying radius inside the sandbox, play with some dials controlling gravity, particle collision, time etc, and watch what happens.
I started it to try and teach myself the C programming language, using the game engine raylib. It remains incomplete (there are some bugs, and there is more physics to add).
If you want to try PhysicsBox yourself, or view the source code, you can visit my GitHub.
title: PhysicsBox

content: I am a PhD student in mathematics at McGill University in Montreal, Canada. My current research focus is on the resolution of singularities in Poisson geometry.

Here you will find a short description of my research interests and experience, as well as a list of my completed theses/dissertations, publications, preprints, posters, talks, and links to attached documents.
Abstract # My current research focus is on my PhD thesis topic: Resolution of Singularities in Poisson Geometry (and Mathematical Physics). My supervisor is Brent Pym.
Prior to my PhD, I completed an MSc (Project) in mathematics at Queen’s University in Kingston, ON, under the supervision of Thomas Barthelmé. My dissertation was Marked Length Spectrum Rigidity of Surfaces.
Prior to my MSc, I completed a BSc in mathematical physics, also at Queen’s University. My BSc thesis Fuzzy Dark Matter Dynamics and the Quasi-Particle Hypothesis was supervised by Lawrence Widrow. This was a project in computational astrophysics. It resulted in my first (and as yet only) publication.
Theses and Projects # Master’s Project: Zupancic, B. M., (2023). “Fuzzy dark matter dynamics and the quasi-particle hypothesis”, Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, Volume 527, Issue 3, January 2024, Pages 6189–6197, https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stad3620.
